Line 1: Line 1: â
The former '''Bryant and May''' match '''factory''' in [[Bow, London]], home of the famous [[1888]] [[Match Girl's strike]] is now a residential development known as the [[Bow Quarter]].
+
The former '''Bryant and May''' match '''factory''' in [[Bow, London]], home of the famous [[1888]] [[London matchgirls strike of 1888|Matchgirls strike]] is now a residential development known as the [[Bow Quarter]].
From the mid [[19th century]] to more than three-quarters of the way through the [[20th century]] the site of the famous [[Bryant and May]] match-making operation. At one point at the turn of the two centuries it was [[London]]'s largest factory.
From the mid [[19th century]] to more than three-quarters of the way through the [[20th century]] the site of the famous [[Bryant and May]] match-making operation. At one point at the turn of the two centuries it was [[London]]'s largest factory.
Line 5: Line 5:
The site acquired by [[William Bryant]] and Francis May in [[1861]] had once been used for the manufacture of [[candle]]s, [[crinoline]] and [[rope]] but had fallen into disrepair.
The site acquired by [[William Bryant]] and Francis May in [[1861]] had once been used for the manufacture of [[candle]]s, [[crinoline]] and [[rope]] but had fallen into disrepair.
â
The factory saw many famous historical events: the Match Girls' Strike of 1888 started here, for example, culminating in the establishment of the first British [[trade union]] for women. A [[blue plaque]] outside the entrance commemorates the role of social pioneer and [[feminism|feminist]] [[Annie Besant]] in leading the demands for better pay and conditions.
+
The factory saw many famous historical events: the [[London matchgirls strike of 1888]] started here, for example, culminating in the establishment of the first British [[trade union]] for women. A [[blue plaque]] outside the entrance commemorates the role of social pioneer and [[feminism|feminist]] [[Annie Besant]] in leading the demands for better pay and conditions.
Bryant and May were influential in fighting against the dreadful disease known as [[Phossy jaw]], caused by the [[phosphorus]] used in the manufacture of [[match|matches]]. Some of the first welfare institutions in Britain for industrial workers began on this site.
Bryant and May were influential in fighting against the dreadful disease known as [[Phossy jaw]], caused by the [[phosphorus]] used in the manufacture of [[match|matches]]. Some of the first welfare institutions in Britain for industrial workers began on this site.
